I20050215-2300

- in a 5.0 java project (with an 5.0 JRE with source attachement), create class:

public class X {
	Vector v= null;
}

- open Help view
- click into Vector

A dangerous looking "Internal Error" dialog says an SWT Error has occurred and
asks whether I want to exit the workbench.

Dejan,
This is because the description contains <E> as part of the text, and it is 
not a styling tag.
For M5 we should xml encode string from IContext.getText() before passing it 
to the form.
If more time (can be post M5) we should implement IContext.getStyledText() to 
return XML fragment, and hopefully, that will be OK to pass to the form as is.

To throw a SWTError seems to be a bug. At most it should be a runtime exception
(IllegalArgumentException), but never an error.

I doubt that this is conformant to the SWT conventions. SWTErrors should be
thrown when an unrecoverable (OS) error happened. The javadoc of
SWT.ERROR_CANNOT_SET_TEXT says it should be used if "... the underlying
operating system was unable to set the text of a widget."

The situation here is more like an IllegalArgumentException (or, better yet, a
new IllegalFormText exception, which clients can catch explicitly).

I escaped text so that all the tags are passed escaped i.e. tags will appear 
in text for now.

In addition, FormText will not throw IllegalArgumentException instead of error 
(by calling SWT.error(SWT.ERROR_INVALID_ARGUMENT, e);).

Sorry, but this is not fixed (using I20050217-0800). It looks as if
IContext.getText() and IContext2.getStyledText() has been fixed but not
IHelpResource.getLabel().

You can test with the following scenario using either JDT UI from HEAD or
upcoming I20050217-1600:
1. create Java project using J2SE 5.0
2. create a CU that uses HashMap
3. select HashMap
==> error
I cannot reproduce this with 0217-2000. Can you?

Also reducing to normal severity because FormText now throws 
IllegalArgumentException instead of SWTError for input parsing problems.

Steps to reproduce in I20050217-2000:
- start with new workspace and an *1.4.2* VM
- create a new java project
- open the project's properties and set its compiler compliance level to 5.0
    (Java Compiler > Enable project specific settings)
- on the Java Build Path page, double-click the JRE System Library [jdk1.4.2],
add a jdk1.5.0 to the installed JREs and select this new one as "Alternate JRE"
- create class p.C:
import java.util.HashMap;
public class C {
	HashMap hm;
}
- set caret into HashMap and press F1

=> you get 3 error dialogs and log entries like this:

Javadoc for 'java.util.HashMap<K, V>'

I am now escaping the IHelpResource label as well. Thanks for the reproducable 
scenario.
